awd_titl_txt: CHS:  Small:  Novel Technology Augmented Methods to Improve Team-based Engineering Education for Diverse Teams
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop an automated system to measure core team processes.  Teams are increasingly prevalent in today's workforce, and the ability to work effectively in teams is a competitive advantage. As a result, team-based learning is now widespread in universities across all levels, ranging from first-year engineering design courses to senior capstone projects. The rise of team-based learning has created two inter-related challenges in effectively delivering the optimal benefits of this learning modality. First, while educators have matured in evaluating technical learning, such as quality of results and presentation, they are still in the early stages of understanding, measuring, and educating students on the process of effective teamwork itself. Second, team-based research relies almost exclusively on self-report measures and human observation, which are error prone and problematic. Thus, there is a clear need to augment current methods so scientists and educators can better measure the processes that lead to effective team performance. The project will impact not only team-based education, but behavioral sciences more broadly. By developing methods to objectively measure behavioral correlates of important psychological constructs, behavioral sciences will go beyond the traditional tools for research.

Grounded in psychological theory and research, and enabled by advances in engineering, this research will leverage two forms of team interactions to understand key metrics related to individual effectiveness, team dynamics, and the impact of diversity on both individual and team metrics: (1) in-person interactions measured from the audio-visual recordings of team meetings, and (2) work interactions measured from team's shared written online collaborative documents. The system developed through this research will include novel methods to extract action sequences from audio-visual meeting data and from the online documents.  Data will be collected in a series of projects across three team environments: (1) targeted studies where teams are formed for 90-minute project sprints; (2) medium-term teams working on a 7-week engineering design internship, and (3) longer-term teams in a semester-long engineering design course. Validated psychological assessments and new metrics will be collected and assembled into an extensive and diverse dataset. A multilayer network model will be developed to represent the different modes of human interaction collected in the individual action sequences. The objective is to extract network features that correlate with meaningful psychological indicators of team dynamics and role emergence within teams.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Effective teamwork is essential in the modern workplace to solve the complex problems of today, which require a diverse set of knowledge, skills, and abilities that no single worker can possess. The NSF-funded TeamDNA project aimed to understand effective team processes, particularly as related to communication and team composition, and to develop methods for studying and measuring those processes. The project team - comprised of engineers and social scientists - used existing theories of effective team behavior from social sciences and applied them to large datasets collected unobtrusively during team interactions to create tools, measures, and models of effective team behavior that can be used in future research and to develop effective teams in organizations. There were three main categories of project outcomes as described below:

TeamDNA Remote: The transition to remote work during the COVID-19 Pandemic required us to move data collection online via Zoom in Spring, 2020. Analyzing transcripts of meetings of teams of students engaging in open-ended and complex engineering design projects over the course of the semester, we showed evidence for the validity of speech patterns (e.g., speaking duration, turn-taking) for predicting team member effectiveness ratings.

Beyond validating measures for future use, we also applied psychological theories of effective communication in TeamDNA remote. We found that team member extraversion affected speaking duration and ultimately ratings of team-member effectiveness provided by teammates. Further, perceptions of psychological safety (i.e., whether team members felt they could openly share their ideas with the team) affected ratings of team member effectiveness. Our results provide evidence that team composition affects perceptions of safety and effectiveness among team members. 

Conversation Model: We developed a model of conversational turn-taking to examine the association between team-member traits (e.g., personality and gender) and turn-taking behavior within teams. The model - which is based on data collected through the TeamDNA project - combines computational modeling with machine learning approaches. The model has been trained on speaking turn data and team member characteristics and can be used to predict speaking patterns in teams based on team composition. 

Team Member Influence: In addition to studying real-world team communication processes as part of TeamDNA remote, our in-lab research used an online task (LineRider.com) to examine how teams integrate disparate ideas of individual team members to solve problems. As part of this study, we developed an objective measure of the influence individuals’ initial ideas had over subsequent designs when either working collaboratively or independently. The results of this research suggest that teams can enhance their performance by ensuring that those who are higher in expertise are free to influence team outcomes. This research also highlights the utility of objective measures of influence in clarifying the behavioral mechanisms underlying idea integration, individual influence, and team performance. The results of this research were also used to develop a computer application for a NASA Moon Landing task that can be used in future research to examine team member influence. 

Intellectual Merit

The project has advanced the science of teamwork in myriad ways. First, through TeamDNA Remote, we validated measures of team processes that can be extracted from naturally occurring conversations and used those measures to support theories of team member composition and psychological safety. We also provided a model for studying team-member composition based on computational modeling and machine learning that can be generalized to novel teams through the Conversation Model, and tools and processes to study the influence individual team members have on team decision-making that will inform research on collective intelligence. Throughout the project, we have developed tasks that can be used in future research (e.g., Line Rider and the NASA Moon Landing Task). From this research, we have published three peer-reviewed journal articles or conference proceedings, two additional papers currently undergoing the peer review process, and three additional conference presentations.

Broader Impacts

The results from our research have implications beyond academic research and promise to improve team effectiveness by providing insight into team composition, team member influence, and the environments in which teams work. The outcomes associated with this project can inform organizations that are increasingly relying on teams to solve complex problems.
